author: Staff Reporter
text:
S. Selvakumar, an artist from the city, was seen painting the head of a majestic bull, complete with long horns and garlands adorning its neck, on a red canvas.

“We’ve all heard only of people trying to tame bulls through force but the song p echi pechi , composed by Ilaiyaraajahas the hero trying to tame the bull by singing the composition to it,” he explained, when asked about the inspiration for his painting.

Around 100 artists like him converged on Loyola College campus on Saturday to paint for ‘Isaioviyam,’ an event celebrating 1,000 films of music maestro Ilayaraja.

The event was organised by the South India Artists Association, director S.P. Jhananathan and Chandrasekaran, former Principal, College of Fine Arts.

Actor Vijay Sethupathy, Nadigar Sangam president Nasser and vice-president Ponvannan were present at the inaugural function.

Mr. Jhananathan said that the finished paintings would be put up for display and sale on the Lalit Kala Akademi premises later in the month and would also be released as a book. “His music has been very effective in recreating the rural milieu for us, which is why I am painting an abstract landscape,” said artist Mathi Velmurugan.
title: Bringing Ilaiyaraaja music alive on canvas
